text: {"answer": "B", "reasoning": "The continuation in B best extends an ECHR argument about exhaustion of domestic remedies in the context of an Article 14 discrimination complaint. It follows a logical pattern where the Court examines whether the applicant properly raised the specific complaint (Article 14/discrimination) before domestic courts before bringing it to the ECHR. This is a standard preliminary objection analysis under Article 35 ยง 1, noting the applicant's failure to raise the issue domestically and questioning whether exhaustion requirements are met. The other options either conclude a different type of analysis (A - manifestly ill-founded), are too generic/fragmentary (C), or address the opposite situation where the Government bears the burden regarding remedy availability (D)."}
